head.title: A Quick Honeymoon for a Caddy at Home at Oakmont

hedline.hl1: A Quick Honeymoon for a Caddy at Home at Oakmont

block.p: Billy Goddard did his job Thursday, which is to say he walked several paces behind his employer and spoke only when spoken to.

Goddard was caddying for Colin Montgomerie, who carded a six-over-par 76 in their first competitive round since their shotgun marriage last week, a union that was precipitated by Montgomerie's firing of his longtime caddie, Alastair McLean.
Billy Goddard did his job Thursday, which is to say he walked several paces behind his employer and spoke only when spoken to.

Goddard was caddying for Colin Montgomerie, who carded a six-over-par 76 in their first competitive round since their shotgun marriage last week, a union that was precipitated by Montgomerie's firing of his longtime caddie, Alastair McLean.

McLean was on Montgomerie's bag in 1994 when he lost to Ernie Els in a playoff the last time the United States Open was played at Oakmont Country Club. Theirs had been an on-again, off-again union, and their latest breakup became official last Friday.
The day before, Goddard, a local resident who said he has been playing Oakmont Country Club for 49 years, hit Montgomerie's radar.
''He called up and said he was looking for a local caddie who knows the course and knows how to keep his mouth shut,'' Goddard said.

Aside from conversations about yardage, Montgomerie and Goddard appeared to exchange few words. On most holes, Montgomerie walked with his head down, a few paces ahead of Goddard, his playing partners Tim Clark and Chris DiMarco, and their caddies.

He started well, with a birdie on his first hole, the par-4 10th. After stringing together six pars, Montgomerie made a bogey on No. 17 when his drive found the second cut of rough and he put his second shot into a deep greenside bunker -- he kicked the divot he left in disgust -- chipped out and two-putted for a 5.
Montgomerie hit 7 of 14 fairways and needed 33 putts.
''He's been good to deal with,'' Goddard said. ''He didn't play too good today, obviously. He hit a couple bad shots and it really cost him. But he got over it.''
SNEDEKER HAS FAST START -- Brandt Snedeker won the United States Amateur Public Links Championship in 2003. That same year, Michelle Wie won the women's version of the event.

Since then, Snedeker, 26, has won twice on the Nationwide tour while Wie, 17, is still looking for her next victory. This year, Snedeker, a graduate of Vanderbilt, has posted two top-five finishes on the PGA Tour and won more than $1 million. On Thursday, he posted his best score in a United States Open, a one-over 71.
''I was able to just keep my head about me,'' said Snedeker, who chipped in for a birdie at the 12th hole to jump-start his round. ''It's a grind out there for five and a half hours.''
